dialogue.speaker: Beaver
dialogue.line: Ah... you‚Äôre finally awake. What a peculiar miracle you are‚Ä¶ and what perfect timing.

Allow me to introduce myself. They call me Marvin, though some in these woods remember me as the sage of the mangrove. I‚Äôve walked among roots and ashes longer than I can count... but never have I seen a creature like you.
Listen. This forest, this home, this world... it‚Äôs withering. Life is fading. The flora is sick. The fauna, maddened. Do you know why?
Not long ago, a gem fell from the sky. A cursed stone, corrupted, alien to all natural form. It shattered, and its energy... spread like poison.
Two fragments. Two cores of power that now pulse uncontrollably, causing mutations, disease... death.

Through my years of study in science, I‚Äôve learned more than you can imagine. I‚Äôm sure that with my knowledge, I could reverse the damage‚Äîbut not with my own qualities. Someone like me cannot move forward against this.
But you... you are not like the others. You could... endure. You could... restore.
If we manage to gather those fragments... we could rebuild the gem. Not to unleash its power, no... but to seal it. To lock the darkness away again. To heal the forest.
Help me, creature. I‚Äôm not asking for violence. Just... do what you already do. What your instinct tells you. Gather what has been lost.

dialogue.speaker: Marvin
dialogue.line: Ah... there you are. Just in time. I knew you wouldn‚Äôt stop. You are‚Ä¶ persistent.
I see you‚Äôve already found one of the fragments. I felt it... from afar. Its energy resonates with you. It‚Äôs... perfect.
You must continue. Further west... in the heart of the high forest lies the second one. Protected, hidden‚Ä¶ corrupted. You must not fail.
The creatures there... are wilder. The corruption runs deep. But you, you only act when necessary, right?
Just keep going. Look for the high places, the hollow canopies. The fragment will find you... just like the first.
But you must hurry, we must act at once or it will be the end of the forest.
Do not delay.

dialogue.speaker: Marvin
dialogue.line: Do you have them?
The fragments, give them to me!
Now's not the time for stalling, slime!
Don‚Äôt be alarmed if you see signs... of battle on me. Sometimes‚Ä¶ trees give way, or animals... fight among themselves. It‚Äôs chaos. The forest is sick. Nothing more.
Everything depends on this. Hand them over!

dialogue.speaker: Marvin Note
dialogue.line: DAY 147 OF THE DRY-STEM CYCLE
Location: Temporary lab, Inner Mangrove
Log Type: Observation Record 004-B
The fragment emits a steady pulse.
Energy oscillates at 11.2 per short cycle.
Surface temperature remains stable,
even in harsh conditions.
When exposed to strong mental stimuli,
especially grief, creation, or longing,
the core shifts in color spectrum.
From deep purple to greenish amber.
It may reflect emotional echoes,
or resonant memory reactions.
This is no crystal. No lifeform either.
It is not of this world.
Its internal geometry is unnatural,
following patterns that defy replication.
Was it discovered by another species?
Or built by them?
Either way, its design surpasses ours
by centuries‚Äîmaybe millennia.
This changes everything.
I remember why I was called a researcher.
This time‚Ä¶ I‚Äôll fix what was broken.

dialogue.speaker: Marvin Note
dialogue.line: Day 163 of the Dry Stem Cycle
Location: Observation Ridge, Deep Roots Sector
Classification: Incident Note 007-A
Something unexpected occurred today.
A hare approached the artifact chamber.
She crossed the wards undetected‚Äî
even the scent traps and sound echoes failed.
She touched the core. Just briefly.
But I saw it: the pulse reacted violently.
It bent toward her like a root seeking water.
Then‚Äîlight. Sharp. Sudden. Gone.
The hare screamed and collapsed,
then stood‚Ä¶ changed.
She wandered away in silence.
I followed. For days, I observed.
She now speaks nonsense‚Äî
phrases from different seasons,
events not yet happened, or long past.
Her mind, I believe, is no longer fixed in time.
The artifact has severed her sequence.
This proves the core's reach over temporality.
Time, to it, is flexible. Subjective. Mutable.
If it can untether memory‚Äî
perhaps it can untether death.

dialogue.speaker: Marvin Note
dialogue.line: Day 174 of the Dry Stem Cycle
Location: Rootfall Sanctuary (sealed chamber)
Classification: Private Entry 011-X
I have stopped sleeping.
The artifact hums even when silent.
It enters dreams I no longer have.
Its angles‚Äî
they continue to grow inside my sketches,
twisting into new dimensions.
I see them now behind leaves and stone.
The forest rejects me, yes, but it does not matter.
What lives inside this core is perfect.
A pattern, recursive and infinite.
Not magic. Not life. Something‚Ä¶ prior.
I was never meant to understand it fully,
but that will not stop me.
Each pulse, each shift, each resonance‚Äî
they bring me closer.
Closer to what was lost.
Closer to what must return.
This world is not ready for it.
But I am.
And I will not let them take this from me again.

dialogue.speaker: Lepus
dialogue.line: Ah! I heard you. Smells like warm mud. It's you, right? I'm Eira.
Hey. Do you know how to open that plug? I've been stuck here for a while... Maybe you can lift it from above mhm‚Ä¶ what should I call you?
You and I‚Ä¶ it always ends the same way... I hope this time hurts less.
Are you helping or not? If we try to lift it... it might open. When you're done, I‚Äôll see you on the other side.

dialogue.speaker: Eira
dialogue.line: Brrr! This is a mess! Who put this burrow here? There's no way to find safety like this.
Don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm hiding in there, friend slime. I‚Äôm not afraid of those monsters. I‚Äôm searching for and opening every burrow in the forest so animals can take shelter.
Still...
don‚Äôt let the darkness consume you again.
Come on slime. Help me unlock it. Who knows, you might even find something interesting. Burrows are where treasures are kept, you know. I‚Äôll see you on the other side.

dialogue.speaker: Eira
dialogue.line: Who are you? You look like someone. Or maybe you're the same person. I don't know... Friend slime? Oh, I didn‚Äôt realize it was you.

Are you going to help me or... just stand there like the others? If you feel like being altruistic, get ready to work. We need to reach that burrow but it's all collapsed. Maybe you can make a path, friend. I‚Äôll see you on the other side.
Thank you, you're the best. You're going to help so many of us who live in the forest. Who wouldn't trust you? Thanks for always using your time to help me. You are...
You are the crack... or the seal. The remnant of hope... or the final step toward oblivion.
After this I‚Äôll head to the Boreal Forest. Follow me if you want to keep helping.
Don't do it! Don‚Äôt look for me in the Boreal Forest!
Come on slime, hurry up! Those shelters won‚Äôt open themselves.

dialogue.speaker: Eira
dialogue.line: üéµ Fresh carrots, crunch in my mouth, I run through the field, I‚Äôll never be alone. üéµ
It hurts,,, it hurt before. Not now. Not... after.
Hello friend slime. You caught me just as I was looking for an injured one in this burrow. I know I ask a lot, but I need your help one more time.
We're still in time to save many.

I heard someone groaning and calling for help down the right path. There are lots of obstacles I can‚Äôt move, but maybe you can. I‚Äôll keep looking for shelters or injured animals down below while you take care of this.
she won‚Äôt survive. She‚Äôll be a prisoner of his obsession. He‚Äôs lying to you, he did this to us‚Ä¶ You can still stop him.
Hey slime, I trust you. See you on the other side, friend!

dialogue.speaker: Eira
dialogue.line: Huh? What are you doing in here? This was my spot...

Ah... Sorry, friend slime. I took shelter wherever I could. I like this place, it's spacious and warm. Feels like before everything. Don‚Äôt you think? I know you won‚Äôt talk, but I‚Äôm sure you agree ha, ha, ha.

We didn‚Äôt have to meet, but something led me here. I guess our future pulled me to our past. You weren‚Äôt like this. At the beginning. Or maybe you were. I don‚Äôt know. Maybe next time will be different...
I want to run... I want to go back to when everything was green‚Ä¶
It won‚Äôt work...
You‚Äôll have to be careful. You can still change things, friend slime. This time
I guess‚Ä¶ see you on the other side‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm ready for before. And you?
Got it! I‚Äôll call you slime, friend slime, or slime friend. Do you like it?

dialogue.speaker: Squirrel
dialogue.line: Woah! That was close! That moldy-smelling specter almost swallowed me whole... They're huge, and honestly, they freak me out. Ah! And what are you? A mutant jelly or a slime with a soul? You're not gonna try to absorb me like they do, right?
Nah, just kidding. Name's Flik. King of the heights! And you? Not much of a talker, huh?

Well then, keep it that way, slippery silence. Sometimes it's better to listen than to babble. I don‚Äôt know what a slimy blob like you is doing here, but if you‚Äôre looking for the entrance to the Boreal Forest, you‚Äôre on the right track. Just be careful‚Äîeasy to slip up ahead. Good luck, little snot!

dialogue.speaker: Flik
dialogue.line: Oh, slippery slime! You‚Äôre looking good‚Äîhope you didn‚Äôt run into any big monsters. Scary, right? Honestly, it‚Äôs amazing you made it through all that with such style. But the style show‚Äôs not over yet. You‚Äôve arrived just in time to help me. I need... something... muscular. Or slimy.
Look, there‚Äôs a chamber up here. I can feel a fresh breeze coming in. But that rock‚Äîoof. It‚Äôs blocking the entrance. Can you push it?
My sister would dive right in without a second thought. Always first. Always faster. Always slipperier...

dialogue.speaker: Flik
dialogue.line: Hey, finally! I thought you got stuck to some log.

I know you‚Äôre wondering what I‚Äôm doing in a place like this. I‚Äôll be honest. When all this started, I lost my little sister. I‚Äôve been looking for her ever since. This place‚Ä¶ I knew it. My sister used to say that stones carry energy.
Do you think rocks really hold energy? Sometimes I feel like I can sense... my sister.
Alright, enough drama. Up here there‚Äôs a spot you might be able to hang from. I bet there‚Äôs a hole up top, and I‚Äôd wager my tail there‚Äôs something awesome hidden in it. Shall we find out?

dialogue.speaker: Flik
dialogue.line: Hehe! Hey there, flying slime!
Everything's under control.
This is part of the aerial training‚Ä¶ Flik Style.
Okay, okay. I‚Äôm stuck. Don‚Äôt laugh!
If you untangle that knot,
I promise to show you a shortcut.
Hey‚Ä¶ Do you think if someone falls‚Ä¶
they can fly again?
My dad used to say a squirrel on a branch
should never fear the branch breaking,
because their trust isn‚Äôt in the branch‚Ä¶
it‚Äôs in their wings.
Forget it. Look, you‚Äôve got two paths.
That hole leads to a hidden chamber.
The other way is a steep exit.
Or you can go back if you‚Äôre not sure.
You choose.
I try to stay positive, y'know‚Ä¶
But I‚Äôm running out of places to look, Slimey.
I‚Äôm losing hope.
But she must be out there, safe.
She has to be.
She always beat me in races‚Ä¶
I know she‚Äôs okay.
But where could she‚Äî
Slimey, if you find her,
make sure she‚Äôs safe‚Ä¶
and lead me to her. Please, buddy.

dialogue.speaker: Flik
dialogue.line: You again. Weird‚Ä¶
I don‚Äôt mind this time.
You know?
I don‚Äôt want to run anymore.
Or hide.
I found her.
Or what was left‚Ä¶
It was her. She had her flower.
The one she wore behind her ear.
Why didn‚Äôt I hear her sooner?
Why didn‚Äôt I protect her?
I found a message she left me.
It said:
‚ÄúDon‚Äôt follow me this time.
I don‚Äôt want you to see me.
Just‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt come. Don‚Äôt come where I‚Äôm going.‚Äù
So of course I followed.
If she saw you‚Ä¶
I think she‚Äôd call you a friend.
You feel different, Slimey.
I don‚Äôt know if I want to,
but since I couldn‚Äôt help her‚Ä¶
I‚Äôll try to help others.
Will you help me up, buddy?

dialogue.speaker: Partridge
dialogue.line: Stop right there, slimeball!
You... what in the roots are you? Not a plant, not a bug, not one of us.
That stench... that rotten slime‚Äîsame as the specters when they burst through our kin.
What foul pit spat you out? You think you belong here, roaming like some forest dweller?
You know what? I don't care. Do as you please.
But hear this: if you keep swallowing everything, this forest might just swallow you too.
And stars know‚ÄîI hope I‚Äôm there to watch it happen.

dialogue.speaker: Partridge
dialogue.line: Oh no... not you.
Of course... is this some cosmic joke?
I‚Äôm trapped... and the only breathing thing around is you?
Don‚Äôt flatter yourself, goo pile. It‚Äôs not trust.
But help me, and maybe‚Äîjust maybe‚Äîyou‚Äôll redeem a single slimy speck of your repulsive existence.
Don't get the wrong idea‚ÄîI‚Äôm not thanking you. Just because you're oozing around doesn't mean you're useful.
Now move it. I don‚Äôt have time to wait for a talking puddle.

dialogue.speaker: Oscar
dialogue.line: Oh... Look at that. Another blob rolling through the woods. What a surprise.
Don‚Äôt worry. I don‚Äôt scream. I don‚Äôt run. I don‚Äôt attack. But I don‚Äôt cheer either.
Do you even know what‚Äôs happening here?
Have you heard the whispers in the branches? The meetings by the old oak?
The council‚Ä¶ our glorious ancestral council‚Ä¶ is falling apart.
The forest families want to seal the borders.
The weasels are raiding the west. And the hares...
...the hares don‚Äôt come anymore. That says it all.
Some blame the Beaver. Pulling strings. Playing god. Vanishing when the curse fell.
Others blame the frogs. Poisoning the wells in the glade.
Meanwhile, the roots rot. No one talks about that.
You‚Ä¶ You‚Äôre new. Foreign. But not unseen.
Some say you‚Äôre needed. Others say you‚Äôre a mistake.
Either way‚Ä¶ keep going, but don‚Äôt say you weren‚Äôt warned.
No council ever voted for your existence.

dialogue.speaker: Unknown Sender
dialogue.line: Day 19 of the Fallen Ferns Cycle
Dear N.,
Sorry for the damp paper and green ink.
Supplies have been low since the last storm.
But I couldn‚Äôt stay silent anymore.
I haven‚Äôt heard from Marvin in days.
Someone saw him near the eastern edge of the mangrove,
but no one‚Äôs managed to get close.
I‚Äôm not surprised, really.
He spent a whole cycle locked in his workshop,
barely stepping into the sunlight.
The last thing he told me was:
‚ÄúI‚Äôm close to something big.‚Äù
I laughed. You know how he was with discoveries.
They were always just about to change the world.
Then the council shut his lab down.
That place was the last thing holding him together.
Days later, youngsters broke in.
They burned and stole everything.
They called it dangerous trash. Maybe they were right.
Still‚Ä¶ no one deserves that.
His wife died five cycles ago,
from some irreversible condition.
His daughter followed three cycles later.
I don‚Äôt know how he didn‚Äôt break sooner.
Or maybe he did, and no one noticed.
I tried. I swear I did.
But he always seemed to talk more to his flasks than to us.
Still‚Ä¶ I worry.
Because when someone that smart is left alone,
that‚Äôs when the dark convinces them they can still fix it all.
If you hear anything, please write back.
Warmly,
‚ÄîY.

dialogue.speaker: Loma
dialogue.line: Day 22 of the Fallen Ferns Cycle
My love,
I don‚Äôt know if this letter will ever reach you,
but I had to write it‚Ä¶ just to feel close to you.
They say you climbed to the top of the Boreal Forest,
looking for shelter‚Ä¶ but why, my dear?
Why didn‚Äôt you come back?
The kids are okay. Tired, yes. Hungry, sometimes. But okay.
Little Kele keeps asking questions.
Today he asked if heroes also have tough scales like yours.
And if he‚Äôll see them again soon.
I‚Ä¶ didn‚Äôt know what to say.
So I told him you‚Äôre building something amazing
at the top of the forest. That you‚Äôll return flying‚Äîlike a bird!
But with a cape!
Then I hid behind the hollow trunk and cried.
I do my best. I sing him your termite-dancing song every night.
Sometimes I mess up on purpose,
just like you did with that awful voice to make us laugh.
Do you remember?
I still keep your clay cup. The one shaped like an acorn.
You said it brought you luck.
No one else touches it.
I just want you to be safe.
If you can‚Äôt come back,
then read this and remember how much I love you.
Come home if you can.
If not‚Ä¶ may the earth hold you,
and may you think of us as you sleep.
Always yours,
‚ÄîLoma

dialogue.speaker: Rulo
dialogue.line: Day 15 of the Fallen Ferns Cycle
Jumito!

An order for thirty-two sacks of fermented manure!
Thirty-two!

someone out there thinks:

At least that market‚Äôs picky.
Write if you survive the week.
I‚Äôll be here‚Ä¶ literally neck-deep.
Smelly love,
‚ÄîRulo
